title: Ping Problems 7.2
body: My ping has always been around 25. Since patch 7.2, it has been 100+ without fail. I have done everything on my end that would possibly fix the problem, router issues, wired connection, etc. No change. Fix this riot.

replies.body:
Sudden increases in latency (ping) are historically caused by ISP routing changes that take a longer path to our servers. Since you've already worked on your local side of things, I'd like to see a traceroute run through [**WinMTR**](http://winmtr.net/) so we can see if there are any issues in your routing. After loading up the app, plug **104.160.131.1** into the host field and start the trace. After 5 minutes has gone by, export the results as text and hit me back with them.

If you run into issues with this, let me know.

Done. I don't know if you can attach a file so I just copied it. If this format doesn't work I can find another way.

|                                      WinMTR statistics                                   |

|                       Host              -   %  | Sent | Recv | Best | Avrg | Wrst | Last |

|------------------------------------------------|------|------|------|------|------|------|

|                       ControlPanel.Home -    0 |  311 |  311 |    1 |    4 |   89 |    1 |

|           lo0-0-lns01-tor2.teksavvy.com -    0 |  311 |  311 |    8 |  110 |  291 |  134 |

|        ae1-2140-bdr01-tor2.teksavvy.com -    0 |  311 |  311 |    9 |  110 |  291 |  123 |

|           ae12-0-bdr01-tor.teksavvy.com -    0 |  311 |  311 |   10 |  109 |  292 |  139 |

|                   No response from host -  100 |   63 |    0 |    0 |    0 |    0 |    0 |

|                           104.160.131.1 -    0 |  311 |  311 |   18 |  117 |  305 |  137

It looks like your latency starts rising inside your own network, where your connection sees spikes of **up to 89ms** before leaving your network. Once your connection takes that first hop out of your network, your latency skyrockets to **291ms** and continues to spike before reaching our servers. This indicates there are issues with your ISP's network infrastructure, and there may be issues with your modem/router. Reaching out to your ISP's tier 2 technical support with this trace should aid them in resolving this with you.

If you have any other questions, let me know.
its averaging at like 115.. which is ridiculous. There is no loss either, meaning it isn't on my end or how my computer is connecting to the server. Fix this shit man.
